items.title: Got an error while generating a docx output in Sphinx
items.body:
1. Installed the sphinx-docxbuilder from https://pypi.org/project/sphinx-docxbuilder/
2. Added 'sphinx-docxbuilder' to 'extensions' in conf.py
3, Ran the following command to generate the documentation
**sphinx-build -b docx docs output**

But, got the following error:
_Exception occurred:
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/sphinx-docxbuilder/builder.py", line 69, in write
    self.info(bold('preparing documents... '), nonl=True)
AttributeError: 'DocxBuilder' object has no attribute 'info'_

items.title: Support for PEP 582 (Python local packages directory)
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I am using [Pyflow](https://github.com/David-OConnor/pyflow), which implements [PEP 582 (Python local packages directory)](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0582/), for documentation built with Sphinx and find some warnings like this in building the document:

```
/path/to/doc/dir/__pypackages__/3.8/lib/sphinx/ext/autosummary/templates/autosummary/base.rst:3: WARNING: Error in "currentmodule" directive:
maximum 1 argument(s) allowed, 3 supplied.
```

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Since the cause of above-mentioned errors is that `.rst` files in the local packages directory are detected in searching for documentation source files, I consider that it would be nice if these files are **automatically** ignored.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Since putting that directory into `exclude_patterns` in `conf.py` can solve this issue in user side, exclusion based on user configuration is another solution.  In that case, it may be nice to provide that directory as one of default entries of that configuration.

**Additional context**
Since this is an easy issue and I already have a fix in my environment, I can submit a PR immediately.  However, I'd like to confirm the direction beforehand here.

items.title: Enabling undoc-members in v3.2.0 triggers `KeyError: 'Shiboken'`
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

With `undoc-members` and v3.2.0 I get an exception.  I do not get an exception with v3.1.2.  Per my local bisecting it was introduced specifically in 88b2ec6c34fb405cf468475e6f2a7754e2c705eb.


```python-traceback
Exception occurred:
  File "/home/altendky/.pyenv/versions/3.8.3/lib/python3.8/typing.py", line 1223, in get_type_hints
    base_globals = sys.modules[base.__module__].__dict__
KeyError: 'Shiboken'
```

In case you aren't familiar, Shiboken2 is the wrapper generator used by PySide2 to wrap the C++ Qt library.  Shiboken filled that role for PySide.  I am using PySide2.  I'm not sure if the lack of the 2 is relevant or not.

QTrio: https://github.com/altendky/qtrio/pull/146/commits/e0d526808a924c95d4c6191070ca21ab9ddab54c
Sphinx: 88b2ec6c34fb405cf468475e6f2a7754e2c705eb

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/altendky/qtrio
cd qtrio
git checkout e0d526808a924c95d4c6191070ca21ab9ddab54c
python3.8 -m venv venv
venv/bin/pip install --upgrade pip setuptools wheel
venv/bin/pip install .[pyside2,docs]
venv/bin/pip install git+https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx@88b2ec6c34fb405cf468475e6f2a7754e2c705eb#egg=sphinx
venv/bin/pip freeze
source venv/bin/activate
cd docs
make html
```

items.title: "Invalid C declaration" on C function with macro after function arguments
items.body:
**Describe the bug** I have a C function definition with a trailing macro which specifies the function as "noreturn" and this gives an error during build, even when this keyword is defined in `c_id_attributes`. **To Reproduce** I have the following on an RST: .. c:function:: void up_exit(int status) noreturn_function; And this on the config: 
c_id_attributes = [
  'FAR',
  'CODE',
  'noreturn_function'
]
And during build I get: 
/home/v01d/coding/nuttx_docs/nuttx/doc/reference/os/arch.rst:225: WARNING: Invalid C declaration: Expected end of definition. [error at 25]
  void up_exit(int status) noreturn_function;
  -------------------------^
**Expected behavior** The macro should be ignored while parsing the function declaration. **Your project** https://github.com/v01d/incubator-nuttx/tree/docs/doc **Environment info** - OS: Ubuntu 20.04 - Python version: 3.8.2 - Sphinx version: 3.1.2 - Sphinx extensions: sphinx.ext.autodoc, recommonmark

items.title: Make the "only" directive play nicer with lists
items.body:
Hi, I would like for the ``only`` directive to play nicely with lists. Using the following snippet: ``` foo: * bar .. only:: html * baz * qux ``` results in the following HTML code when building with the html builder: ```

foo:

  • bar
  • baz
  • qux
``` Notice that 3 lists have actually been created from a single list in the source file. I would like for the list's items to stay as one list, as if the ``only`` directive had never been there in the first place, i.e. ```

foo:

  • bar
  • baz
  • qux
``` Same would be true for other builders. I've also considered using this alternate syntax: ``` toto: * tata * .. only:: html titi * tutu ``` This does result in the expected output when the tag is defined, but results in an empty bullet item when it is not: ```

toto:

  • tata
  • tutu
``` I also tried using the ``ifconfig`` directive instead, to no avail. If this feature gets implemented, it might be worth to support it in ``ifconfig`` too. Best regards, François

markdown files not incorporated into docs with v3.x
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Newer versions of sphinx (3.1.2 and 3.2.0) generate incorrect warnings when working with markdown files and those files are then not incorporated into the documentation. This is in a documentation base which works fine with sphinx 2.4.4

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```
$ git clone https://github.com/greglandrum/sphinx_bug
$ cd sphinx_bug
$ make html

items.title: sphinx 3.2.0: trouble with `typing.get_type_hints`
items.body:
Since 3.2.0, I cannot apply sphinx on my project (neither on Travis-CI nor locally):

```
Exception occurred:
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
NameError: name 'typingtools' is not defined
```
`typingtools` is module only required for typing purposes. Hence, I import it as follows:

```
if TYPE_CHECKING:
    from hydpy.core import typingtools
```

The problem starts in method `AttributeDocumenter.add_directive_header()` in line ```annotations = get_type_hints(self.parent)```.

If I apply the following manually, I get the same error:

```
import typing
from hydpy.models.arma.arma_control import Responses
typing.get_type_hints(Responses)
```

When I add module `typingtools` to the local variables, everything seems to work:

```
import typing
from hydpy.core import typingtools
from hydpy.models.arma.arma_control import Responses
typing.get_type_hints(Responses, localns={'typingtools': typingtools})
```

My project: https://github.com/hydpy-dev/hydpy/tree/develop.

items.title: Sphinx: Indent with 2 spaces, except for toctree which is 3 spaces...
items.body:
From the [documentation](https://documentation-style-guide-sphinx.readthedocs.io/en/latest/style-guide.html). The `toctree` directive is the only one that requires a 3 space indentation. This looks like a glitch in the matrix and it should be fixed in some way.

> Indentation
> Indent with 2 spaces.
> 
> Except:
> 
> toctree directive requires a 3 spaces indentation.

Then I propose enforce what the doc says by adding an `.editorconfig` file that specifies 2 spaces for rST files. 

What do you guys think?

items.title: Napoleon extension gives unexpected error message when processing the docstring of a function written in Cython
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Our CI crashed with a rather cryptic error message when building the documentation, see https://travis-ci.com/github/theochem/iodata/jobs/370345521#L1842

Manual checks revealed this was related to the Napolean extension. (Commenting out napoleon from `conf.py` prevents the error message, but this is not a helpful solution.)

By adding a line `print(obj)` to the function `_process_docstring` in the file `sphinx/ext/napoleon/__init__.py`, the Cython extension appears to be the cause. The error message with the extra print lines then becomes:

```
Extension error:
Handler <function _process_docstring at 0x7f1a9f310cb0> for event 'autodoc-process-docstring' threw an exception (exception: module, class, method, function, traceback, frame, or code object was expected, got builtin_function_or_method)
<module 'iodata.overlap_accel' from '/home/toon/univ/code/iodata/iodata/overlap_accel.cpython-37m-x86_64-linux-gnu.so'>
<built-in function add_overlap>
<built-in function fac2>
make: *** [Makefile:21: html] Error 2
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```bash
git clone git@github.com:theochem/iodata.git
cd iodata
./setup.py build_ext -i
cd doc
make html
```

**Expected behavior**
A more understandable error message would be helpful. Ideally, Napoleon should just process docstrings of "builtin" functions. These are not necessarily built-in to Python. They can be functions from any extension module. 

**Your project**
https://github.com/theochem/iodata/

**Screenshots**
not applicable

**Environment info**
- OS: Fedora 32
- Python version: 3.7.7
- Sphinx version: 3.2.0
- Sphinx extensions:  `sphinx.ext.napoleon`
- Extra tools: none

**Additional context**
not applicable

items.title: Sphinx 3.2.0 gives WARNING: py:class reference target not found: type warning but treated as error
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
I am using Sphinx for autodoc . This bug is regression issue caused in Sphinx==3.2.0,  which relates to 

[https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/issues/965]

I am using absolute path of my class   `kartothek.core.dataset.DatasetMetadata` and Sphinx3.2.0 throws below error.
This worked well, when I used sphinx==3.1.2

`Warning, treated as error:
docstring of xx.yy.zz:py:class reference target not found: A.B.C.D]]
##[error]Process completed with exit code 1.`

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
Install sphinx==3.2.0
Use absolute path of a class in the documentation.

**Expected behavior**
Sphinx to accept the absolute path of the class.

items.title: Highlight warn not the current node location
items.body:
In `writer/html5.py/visit_literal_block` we find this:

        highlighted = self.highlighter.highlight_block(
            node.rawsource, lang, opts=opts, linenos=linenos,
            location=(self.builder.current_docname, node.line), **highlight_args
        )

The good news is that it works in most cases. However if a node is moved during the build process, you'll get an error with the wrong document name as we use the `node.line`, but the current docname.

Wouldn't be better to use `node.source` and `node.line`?

items.title: Warning: Inline literal start-string without end-string in Numpy style Parameters section
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
The following docstring generates a warning on the line of the timeout parameter. Removing the quote around `default` cause the warning to go away.
```python
def lock(
        self,
        timeout: Union[float, Literal["default"]] = "default",
        requested_key: Optional[str] = None,
    ) -> str:
        """Establish a shared lock to the resource.

        Parameters
        ----------
        timeout : Union[float, Literal["default"]], optional
            Absolute time period (in milliseconds) that a resource waits to get
            unlocked by the locking session before returning an error.
            Defaults to "default" which means use self.timeout.
        requested_key : Optional[str], optional
            Access key used by another session with which you want your session
            to share a lock or None to generate a new shared access key.

        Returns
        -------
        str
            A new shared access key if requested_key is None, otherwise, same
            value as the requested_key

        """
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```
$ git clone https://github.com/pyvisa/pyvisa
$ git checkout pytest
$ cd pyvisa
$ pip install -e .
$ cd docs
$ sphinx-build source build -W -b html;
```

**Expected behavior**
I do not expect to see a warning there and was not seeing any before 3.2

**Your project**
The project is build under the Documentation build action. https://github.com/pyvisa/pyvisa/pull/531

**Environment info**
- OS: Mac Os and Linux
- Python version: 3.8.2 and 3.8.5
- Sphinx version: 3.2.0
- Sphinx extensions: "sphinx.ext.autodoc", "sphinx.ext.doctest","sphinx.ext.intersphinx", "sphinx.ext.coverage", "sphinx.ext.viewcode", "sphinx.ext.mathjax",  "sphinx.ext.napoleon"

See also: https://gitlab.tiker.net/inducer/islpy/-/jobs/148860

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```
git clone https://github.com/inducer/islpy.git
curl -L -O -k https://gitlab.tiker.net/inducer/ci-support/raw/master/build-docs.sh
. ./build-docs.sh
```

**Environment info**
- OS: Debian Linux

items.title: autodoc does not recognize cython_function_or_method
items.body:
First of all, congratulations on the new release 3.2!  I've been waiting for it for quite a while.

### Describe the bug

When I try to build the HTML pages using `make html`, autodoc throw an exception about not expecting cython_function_or_method.  On Sphinx 3.1.2 this doesn't happen.

### To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```console
$ git clone --single-branch --branch gh-pages https://github.com/McSinyx/palace
$ cd palace
$ pip install palace==0.2.1 Sphinx==3.2.0
$ cd docs
$ make htmlRunning Sphinx v3.2.0
building [mo]: targets for 0 po files that are out of date
building [html]: targets for 17 source files that are out of date
updating environment: [new config] 17 added, 0 changed, 0 removed
reading sources... [ 35%] reference/buffer                                                                                                                                      
Extension error:
Handler <function _process_docstring at 0x7f47a189c550> for event 'autodoc-process-docstring' threw an exception (exception: module, class, method, function, traceback, frame, or code object was expected, got cython_function_or_method)
make: *** [Makefile:20: html] Error 2
```

Currently palace only have binary builds for Python 3.6+ on GNU/Linux (and for Python 3.6 on macOS, but I doubt if anyone is still using Python 3.6 anymore), so if you don't have GNU/Linux I'll work out a more minimal Cython module to facilitate the debugging progress.

### Your project

For convenience purposes, I'm leaving a snapshot of our project gh-pages branch here as well: [palace-gh-pages.zip](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/files/5045123/palace-gh-pages.zip)

### Environment info

- OS: Debian GNU/Linux testing
- Python version: 3.8.5
- Sphinx version: 3.2.0
- Sphinx extensions:  sphinx.ext.autodoc
- Extra tools: [Cython 0.29.21](https://travis-ci.com/github/McSinyx/palace/jobs/369952579)

items.title: sphinx-build seems to be dangerous
items.body:
When running `sphinx-build` command, it seems to be dangerous to execute python scripts.

A third-party library, named `sphinx-autoapi` and developed by `readthedocs` organization, uses `astroid` to parse ast, which seems to be a little safer in some way.

Detailed description can be found here: 
[Is sphinx-build extremely dangerous? Or is it just me?](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/sphinx-users/7quQx2r4dGc)

items.title: Running LinkCheck on Git Diff
items.body:
This would be useful to avoid websites blocking us (CI) because we're pinging the same URL many many times.

The reason I brought this issue up, is it seems websites are blocking our CI linkcheck, causing us to consistently exclude URLs, even though these URLs should be checked.

items.title: An annotated instance variable on super class is not documented when derived class has other annotated instance variables
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
An annotated instance variable on super class is not documented when derived class has other annotated instance variables

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```
# example.py
class Foo:
    var1: int


class Bar(Foo):
    var2: int
```
```
# index.rst
.. automodule:: example
   :members:
   :undoc-members:
   :inherited-members:
```

`Bar.var1` is not shown even if `:inherited-members:` option given.

**Expected behavior**
Both `var1` and `var2` are shown.

**Your project**
No

**Screenshots**
No

**Environment info**
- OS: Mac
- Python version: 3.8.2
- Sphinx version: HEAD of 3.x
- Sphinx extensions:  sphinx.ext.autodoc

items.title: No way for a directive to force document rebuilds
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
I've built an extension that injects a subprocess output into the document. And by its nature, every re-run of `sphinx-build` should refresh its contents.

I know that there's a user-side way to do this, i.e. the end-user would have to _remember_ to pass `-a` or specify that document explicitly when running `sphinx-build`. But this is on very user-friendly and requires them to _know upfront_ that the cached doctrees that prevent document rebuilds will also prevent the directive re-invocation.

**Expected behavior**

I saw some prevention mechanisms in other places. Like, when an extension declares some config value, it can specify the `rebuild=` arg to make Sphinx force rebuilds on config changes. I'd like to have some mechanism to do the same for directives. Like specifying that if a document has the directive, it should always be rebuilt. Or maybe, re-run such directives to decide if the document should be taken from the doctree or be rebuilt.
Another thought is that it'd be interesting if a directive could declare that its own caching depends on whether certain files or directories have changed. In my case, this variant would be perfect because I invoke towncrier and towncrier basically takes a bunch of RST files and outputs them as one bigger RST (using Jinja2 internally tho).

Ref: https://github.com/sphinx-contrib/sphinxcontrib-towncrier/issues/1
Ref: https://stackoverflow.com/a/44758406/595220

items.title: Support defining specific `:private-members:` for autodoc
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently, if I'm using autodoc, the `:private-members:` option does not allow specification of which private members to document. The current behavior is to document all private members, but what if I would only like to document 1 or 2?

**Describe the solution you'd like**
For `:private-members:` to take arguments, similarly to how `:members:` currently works

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
The current best way to do this is to explicitly list each class in a module and use `:autoattribute:`

- Some prior discussion: https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/issues/8009

since a few weeks I've got this error from latest git version:
```
$ python -c "import  sphinx.directives"
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/devel/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sphinx/directives/__init__.py", line 19, in <module>

AttributeError: partially initialized module 'sphinx.addnodes' has no attribute 'versionmodified' (most likely due to a circular import)
```

It seems to come from fb7b0ee5718af07c8eddf49f71742f6b97f7fd65:
```
$ git clone https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx.git && cd sphinx && git bisect start 2cf3e7cae2a7677bc3b2b87456a9129f426d27e1 68abe09afe9f33a3ce0ea4e909a78377b2069ddf && echo -e "#!/bin/sh\npython setup.py install --user\npython -c 'import sphinx.directives'" > /tmp/brun.sh && chmod a+rx /tmp/brun.sh && cat /tmp/brun.sh && $ git bisect run /tmp/brun.sh
...
fb7b0ee5718af07c8eddf49f71742f6b97f7fd65 is the first bad commit
commit fb7b0ee5718af07c8eddf49f71742f6b97f7fd65
Author: Takeshi KOMIYA <i.tkomiya@gmail.com>
Date:   Tue May 5 22:12:52 2020 +0900

items.title: WARNING: py:class reference target not found: typing.Callable[...<snip>
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
```python
@typing.overload
def host(
    func: typing.Callable[..., typing.Awaitable[object]]
) -> typing.Callable[..., object]:
    ...


@typing.overload
def host(
    *, timeout: float = 3
) -> typing.Callable[
    [typing.Callable[..., typing.Awaitable[object]]], typing.Callable[..., object]
]:
    ...


# TODO: not really sure...
# qtrio/_pytest.py:37: error: Overloaded function implementation does not accept all possible arguments of signature 1
# qtrio/_pytest.py:37: error: Overloaded function implementation does not accept all possible arguments of signature 2
@decorator.decorator  # type: ignore
@pytest.mark.usefixtures("qapp", "qtbot")
def host(
    func, timeout=3, *args, **kwargs,
):
```

Results in:

```
/home/altendky/repos/preqtrio/qtrio/_pytest.py:docstring of qtrio.host:: WARNING: py:class reference target not found: typing.Callable[..., typing.Awaitable[object]]

git clone https://github.com/altendky/qtrio

The error doesn't happen.

items.title: Instance attributes are omitted with autosummary
items.body:
This issue is a followup of #7948. Sorry, I forgot to open it.

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Instance attributes are omitted when using the autosummary, as they cannot be imported. Consider the following class

```python
# contents of test_mod.py

class Test:
    """Test class"""

    #: int. Some class attribute
    test: int = 1

    def __init__(self, a: int):
        #: int. An instance attribute
        self.a = 1

```

`autodoc` via 

```rst
.. autoclass:: Test
    :members:
``` 

will document the `a` attribute, but `autosummary` via

```rst
.. autosummary::

    Test.a
    Test.test
```
won't.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Instance attributes should be documented, too

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
it did work before 1dcfc44, i.e. for `sphinx<3.1` (although the documentation was omitted).

**Additional context**

- #7948
- files to reproduce the issue (including page build) [test.zip](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/files/4982157/test.zip)
- Screenshot of index.html
  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9960249/88545154-ddf88400-d01a-11ea-906c-193e39fbb4d3.png)

items.title: Sphinx throws an "unexpected indentation" error for abstract methods
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
It seems sphinx is not properly detecting abstract private methods and is falsely reported an "undexpected indenation" docstring error.

```rst
.. automodule:: nbapy.game
   :members:
   :private-members: _endpoint
   :undoc-members:
   :show-inheritance:
```

```python
# game.py

class _BoxScore(ABC):
    @property
    @classmethod
    @abstractmethod
    def _endpoint(cls):
        return NotImplementedError

# ... # 

class BoxScore(_BoxScore):
    _endpoint = "boxscoretraditionalv2"

```

```bash
$ sphinx-build -n -W -q -b html docs docs/_build/html

Warning, treated as error:
/home/jacob/src/nbapy/nbapy/game.py:docstring of nbapy.game._BoxScore._endpoint:12:Unexpected indentation.
````

I'd like to document _endpoint in all the classes that inherit _BoxScore


**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```
$ git clone https://github.com/jtpavlock/nbapy
$ cd nbapy
$ poetry install
$ sphinx-build -n -W -q -b html docs docs/_build/html
```

**Expected behavior**
Sphinx to not throw this warning

**Your project**
[nbapy](https://github.com/jtpavlock/nbapy)

**Environment info**
- OS: Ubuntu 20.04
- Python version: 3.8.2
- Sphinx version: sphinx-build 3.1.2
- Sphinx extensions:  
```
extensions = [
    "sphinx.ext.autodoc",
    "sphinx.ext.napoleon",
    "sphinx_rtd_theme",
]
```
- Extra tools: none

items.body:
**Describe the bug**
```python
@decorator.decorator
def host(
    func: typing.Callable[..., typing.Awaitable[None]],
    timeout: float = 3,
    *args,
    **kwargs
):
```

items.title: Allow searching for serials, phone numbers, tickets, etc
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Numeric pieces of text are not indexed and cannot be searched for. For example, a ticket number like 0123456789 doesn't show up when searching.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Don't filter out numeric pieces of text anymore.

items.title: copy button copies `>>>` lines, but doesn't copy "..." lines
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

When the copy button is clicked on a code like [this](https://huggingface.co/transformers/quicktour.html#using-the-tokenizer):

```
>>> pt_batch = tokenizer(
...     ["We are very happy to show you the 🤗 Transformers library.", "We hope you don't hate it."],
...     padding=True,
...     truncation=True,
...     return_tensors="pt"
... )
```

only the first line is copied. 

All lines starting with `>>>` get copied, but `...` lines are ignored. So for example, [this](https://huggingface.co/transformers/quicktour.html#customizing-the-model) gets fully copied:

```
>>> from transformers import DistilBertConfig, DistilBertTokenizer, DistilBertForSequenceClassification
>>> config = DistilBertConfig(n_heads=8, dim=512, hidden_dim=4*512)
>>> tokenizer = DistilBertTokenizer.from_pretrained('distilbert-base-uncased')
>>> model = DistilBertForSequenceClassification(config)
```

I was told that this could be `sphinx_copybutton`.

**To Reproduce**

e.g. click the copy button at this url and scroll a few lines down to the third code section at:
https://huggingface.co/transformers/quicktour.html#using-the-tokenizer

**Expected behavior**

lines starting with `...` should be copied just as they do for lines starting with `>>>`

**Your project**
https://huggingface.co/transformers/

**Environment info**

I'm just a user, so I'm not sure about the environment.
All I know is that it says at the bottom of the page, that it uses this theme:
https://github.com/rtfd/sphinx_rtd_theme
I'd be happy to ask for more details if needed.

I was able to reproduce it in the latest firefox and chrome on linux.

items.title: translated `.. math::` interprets escapes twice
items.body:
When rendering a translated `.. math::`, escapes aren't properly ignored when parsing the translation.

This string, properly escaped:
```latex
c_1 \oplus c_2 (\text{définition})
```
gets rendered to 

```latex  
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}begin{aligned} c_1 oplus c_2 (text{définition}) end{aligned}\end{split}
\end{equation*}
```

my understanding is that `sphinx.transforms.i18n.Locale.apply` calls `publish_msgstr`, which interprets `\` as `\x00` 

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```
$ git clone https://github.com/multun/crypto101-sphinx-bugreport
$ cd crypto101-sphinx-bugreport
$ python3 -m sphinx -b latex -E -a -D language='fr'  src _build_fr
$ grep oplus _build_fr/latex/python.tex
```

**Expected behavior**

The fact the text comes from a math section is taken into account, and the text is unchanged during post-gettext translation parsing.

**Your project**
We're translating [Crypto101](https://github.com/crypto101/book), an open source book about cryptography!

**Environment info**
- OS: Linux
- Python version: tested on 3.8.2, 3.7.5
- Sphinx version: tested on master (c2df631), 1.8.5, 2.2.2
- Sphinx extensions:  none
- Extra tools: none

items.title: Code blocks use short pygments class names, but inline code uses long ones
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

This error was originally reported on https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21591107/sphinx-inline-code-highlight

`code-block` directives use short pygments class names.  Inline code snippets (the `code` role), on the other hand, use long Pygments class names.  As a result, inline code snippets are not properly highlighted.

**To Reproduce**

```bash
$ mkdir /tmp/sphinx
$ cd /tmp/sphinx
$ sphinx-quickstart
…
$ # edit index.rst as shown below
$ tail index.rst
* :ref:`search`

.. role:: bash(code)
   :language: bash

Test inline: :bash:`export FOO="bar"`.

.. code-block:: bash

    export FOO="bar"
$ make html
Makefile:20: warning: undefined variable 'O'
…
The HTML pages are in _build/html.
$ firefox _build/html/index.html 
```

**Expected behavior**
Both code snippets should be highlighted.  Insetad, only the code block is highlighted.  The inlien snippet has pygments classes applied, but they use long class names, and so they don't match the syntax-highlighting CSS rules, which use short class names.

**Environment info**
- OS: GNU/Linux (Linux Mint 20)
- Python version: Python 3.8.2
- Sphinx version: sphinx-build 3.0.4
- Sphinx extensions: None
- Extra tools: Firefox

items.title: Improve deprecated_alias warnings
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Consider this warning generated by [`deprecated_alias`](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/blob/293fa1e5fc7ee663cb2b2c7e446623773fa9735a/sphinx/directives/__init__.py#L281):
```
>>> from sphinx.directives import SeeAlso
__main__:1: RemovedInSphinx40Warning: sphinx.directives.SeeAlso is deprecated. Check CHANGES for Sphinx API modifications.
```
That makes it sound like `SeeAlso` is being removed in Sphinx 4.0 when in reality it seems to only be that importing from `sphinx.directives` is deprecated. That really isn't clear from the warning.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The warning should specify it's just the alias that's depreacted and tell you what the canonical version is. e.g.

> The alias "sphinx.directives.SeeAlso" is deprecated, use "sphinx.directives.other.SeeAlso" instead. Check CHANGES for Sphinx API modifications.

items.title: autosummary strips docstrings after the first dot
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

`autosummary` strips docstrings after the first "." sign.

**To Reproduce**

a.py:
```python
"""The best module. Ever."""
```

a.rst
```
.. autosummary::

    a
```

output (no " Ever." part):
```
a | The best module.
```

**Environment info**
- OS: Mac/Win/other with version]
- Python version: 3.6.10
- Sphinx version: 3.1.2
- Sphinx extensions:  sphinx.ext.autodoc, sphinx.ext.autosummary, sphinx.ext.doctest, sphinx.ext.intersphinx, sphinx.ext.napoleon, sphinx.ext.viewcode

items.title: Default value of inspect.Parameter.empty breaks autofunction signature
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
When you have a function with (at least) 2 optional parameters and the default value for the 2nd parameter is `inspect.Parameter.empty`, something goes wrong and the documentation generated for this function will not display
any parameters at all in the signature.

**To Reproduce**
Create a python function like this:
```python
import inspect

def func(optional_arg1='whatever',
         optional_arg2=inspect.Parameter.empty,
         ):
    """lorem ipsum"""
```
Document it with the `autofunction` directive:
```rst
.. autofunction:: func
```
Run `make html` and observe the missing parameters in the output:
```
package_name.func()¶
    lorem ipsum
```

**Expected behavior**
The function's parameters should show up in the documentation. I understand that it's difficult to deal with `inspect.Parameter.empty` as a default value, but completely omitting the function's parameters without any kind
of error or warning is not acceptable.

**Environment info**
- OS: linux
- Python version: 3.8
- Sphinx version: 3.1.2
- Sphinx extensions:  sphinx.ext.autodoc

items.title: Issue with . notation in methode name, e.g. overwriting coder.typeof
items.body:
The parser cannot handle function names with a "." in them, such as coder.typeof.

  end

      obj.tmp = t;
    end

end
```

items.title: "Include file '...' not found or reading it failed" should be an error, not a warning
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
When I have an invalid `literalinclude` directive, the error saying that it could not be found is only a warning. It should be an error (or there should be a way to make it an error, without making all other warnings, many of which may be benign, into errors).

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior: make a rst file with a `.. literainclude:: asfkdjsfkdjafkds`.

**Expected behavior**
Build fails with error

items.title: Regression: autodoc Dataclass variables reference target not found
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

When I use `sphinx.ext.autodoc` and `nitpicky = True` with my code which includes a dataclass with a variable of a custom type, I get a warning.

**To Reproduce**

Open the attached project [sphinx-example.zip](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/files/4890646/sphinx-example.zip).
Install Sphinx.
Run `sphinx-build -M html source/ build/`.

**Expected behavior**

I expect there to be no warning, or a clear message saying how I can avoid this warning.

**Your project**

[sphinx-example.zip](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/files/4890646/sphinx-example.zip)

**Environment info**

macOS latest
Python 3.7.7
Sphinx 3.1.2 (reproducible also with 3.1.0 but not 3.0.4)

items.title: Building the Sphinx documentation using 'make latexpdf' fails
items.body:
Trying to build a PDF of the Sphinx 3.1.2 manual using `make latexpdf` in the docs directory fails with

    ! LaTeX Error: Unknown graphics extension: .svg.

Should `sphinx.ext.imgconverter` be added to the list of extensions in _conf.py_?

items.title: Autosummary with custom documenters
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
This is related to #6264, but a bit different (I think?): when using the `template` option of `autosummary` directives, `autosummary` will ignore the template which means it will use the wrong documenter to produce its summary table.

For an example, see [sphinx-autosummary-accessors](https://github.com/keewis/sphinx-autosummary-accessors) ([examples.rst](https://github.com/keewis/sphinx-autosummary-accessors/blob/aa44bda88a5e8a828bdff5b80b0ee522c201d719/docs/examples.rst), [build](https://sphinx-autosummary-accessors--6.org.readthedocs.build/en/6/examples.html))

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I'd like `autosummary` to use the documenter specified in the template instead of choosing from the standard documenters.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I considered using the priority to control the directive used but that would mean those directives are always used and not only together with the template.

In keewis/sphinx-autosummary-accessors#6 (https://github.com/keewis/sphinx-autosummary-accessors/pull/6/commits/aa44bda88a5e8a828bdff5b80b0ee522c201d719) I hacked around that by overriding `Autosummary.get_items` to extract that information from the template and use the correct documenter. That, however, is fragile since now I need to make sure this stays in sync with the upstream method.

items.title: viewcode fails to execute when autodoc is not used
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
When viewcode is enabled (autodoc is disabled), the plugin fails to execute

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

file a.c
```
#include "a.h"
static uint8_t abcd[4]; 
uint8_t abcd12(uint8_t a,uint16_t b)
{
    a=b;
    abcd[2]=a;
}
```
file a.h
```
#include <stdint.h>
uint8_t abcd12(uint8_t a,uint16_t b);
```
snippet of conf.py
```
author = 'AUTHOR'

extensions = [
'sphinx.ext.todo',
'sphinx.ext.graphviz',
'sphinx.ext.viewcode',
]
```
file code.rst
```
Code page
=========

.. graphviz::

   digraph foo {
    "bar" -> "baz";
   }
 
.. todo:: This is a todo for test
 
.. c:function:: uint8_t abcd12(uint8_t a,uint16_t b)
 
   The above function takes in a and b and returns an uint8_t data
 
   :param uint8_t a: a parameter
   :param uint8_t b: another parameter 
   :return: the return variable
 
.. todo:: This is an extra todo for test
```
after adding code.rst to index.rst and running
```
sphinx-build . _build
```
**Expected behavior**
There should be a link to the source code which is not seen.


**Environment info**
- OS: Linux Ubuntu
- Python version: [e.g. 3.6.9]
- Sphinx version: [e.g. 3.1.0]
- Sphinx extensions:  [e.g. sphinx.ext.viewcode,sphinx.ext.todo,sphinx.ext.graphviz]

**Additional context**
Sphinx installed using pip.Other extensions todo and graphviz work as expected.
For this testing, the c and header files are in the same folder as conf.py,index.rst,code.rst

I want this clarified, can the viewcode not used without autodoc ? Do I need to use
something else like module etc

items.title: globaltoc_maxdepth
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

It is currently impossible to configure the sidebar TOC to collapse and expand to the current page, while also limiting the local TOC to depth 1.

[Small example project](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/files/4213173/test-sphinx.zip) from #7171

**Describe the solution you'd like**

The `globaltoc_maxdepth` theme option should allow configuring the sidebar independently from the local TOC.
Then:
```
html_theme_options = {
    'globaltoc_collapse': True,
    'globaltoc_maxdepth': -1,
}
```

should make the sidebar behave as desired, even when the local TOC's are limited like this:

```
.. toctree::
   :maxdepth: 1
   
   sub/index
```

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I've tried many combinations of the existing theme options, toctree directive options, `:tocdepth:`, `:titlesonly:`, `:hidden:`, `:includehidden:`, `globaltoc_collapse`, `collapsiblesidebar` etc.

**Additional context**

- @mgeier suggested in https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/issues/7171 I should open this issue
- @tk0miya previously discussed it in https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/pull/7443

items.title: Unresolved types when using typing.overload and the autodoc extension
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
When using @typing.overload in a python module, the parameter types do not get expanded like they do for regular functions, and as a result they also do not get linked to the docs for the corresponding type.

The same is true for the function's return type.

**To Reproduce**
Download the attached project, and run `sphinx-build -bhtml . _build`
[overload_issue.zip](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/files/4855462/overload_issue.zip)

The important part is this:
```python
import my_module
import my_module as other_name

@typing.overload
def bad(i: my_module.A) -> my_module.A:
    pass

@typing.overload
def bad(i: "my_module.B") -> "my_module.B":
    pass

@typing.overload
def bad(i: other_name.C) -> other_name.C:
    pass

@typing.overload
def bad(i: D) -> D:
    pass
```
The _first_ overload links fine, because the full module path to A is spelled out, but the second overload retains the quotes around the parameter and return type, the third overload retains "other_name" as the module name, and the fourth leaves the module off, just like it's written.

In the attached file, there are also "good" functions that repeat the same patterns but without using `@typing.overload`, and those all resolve correctly and link to the corresponding type (A, B, C, or D) in the docs.

**Expected behavior**
The documentation for the "bad" functions should link to the parameter/return types just as well as the "good" functions.

**Your project**
Attached (in the "To Reproduce" section).
(And I have a real project for which I have worked around this issue by hiding the overloads from the docs, but it's not yet posted to GitHub.)

**Screenshots**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7470942/86199878-e1cede80-bb20-11ea-8d1f-434348a4bc30.png)


**Environment info**
- OS: Win 10
- Python version: 3.8.2
- Sphinx version: 3.1.1
- Sphinx extensions:  sphinx.ext.autodoc
- Extra tools: Browser

**Additional context**
none

items.title: C domain changes of Sphinx 3 prevent to write doc compatible with Sphinx 2 and Sphinx 3
items.body:
The Python documentation can be found in the Doc/ directory of https://github.com/python/cpython/ It is quite big: 262k lines of .rst files (and 1300 of extensions written in Python: see Doc/tools/).

It is no longer possible to build the Python documentation with Sphinx 3, many syntax which were allowed previously ("tolerated"?) are now treated as errors: see https://bugs.python.org/issue40204 for details.

According to the Sphinx changelog, it is a deliberate that the C domain is more strict. Extract:

> The C domain has been rewritten, with additional directives and roles. The existing ones are now more strict, resulting in new warnings.

The problem is that I fail to find a way to write a documentation which can be built and rendered properly with Sphinx 2 **and** Sphinx 3. Dropping Sphinx 2 support is not an option for the Python project. Too many Linux distributions currently build the Python documentation with Sphinx 2, and it seems like upgrading to Sphinx 3 will break at least Python, but likely other projects documentation.

It seems like we have the following options for the Python documentation:

* Stay at Sphinx forever
* Backport the ":c:struct:" and ":c:expr:" markups somehow in Sphinx 2 using our CPython Sphinx extensions
* Update Sphinx 3 to tolerate our "incorrect" documentation using :c:type: and :c:type:`PyObject\*` (invalid C syntax), maybe as an opt-in option
* Update Sphinx 2 to support Sphinx 3 new syntax: something like Python 2.7 which backported a few Python 3 features like b"bytes string" syntax

Example of issue: `.. c:struct: MyStruct` is required by Sphinx 3 to document a structure, since ``.. c:type: MyStruct` is now treated as an error. But with Sphinx 2, `.. c:struct: MyStruct` section is simply ignored and the whole section miss from the HTML output.

cc @birkenfeld

items.title: TODO example is missing env-merge-info
items.body:
Looks like the [tutorials/todo](https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/development/tutorials/todo.html) example is missing the `env-merge-info` step to make it work for parallel builds.

In cpython we use a similar pattern, and it was not working in parallel builds, I added it like this: https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/21237

Am I right? If so I can add it to the example.

items.title: apidoc generates an extra newline at the end of the rst file if a module has submodules
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
This is not really a bug but rather an annoyance if you are using pre-commit hooks that format end of file, as it would often make commits fail that wouldn't otherwise.

**To Reproduce**
Create a package with at least one submodule. and use apidoc on it. Something like this
```
├── docs
│   ├── conf.py
│   ├── index.rst
│   ├── make.bat
│   ├── Makefile
│   ├── package
│   │   ├── modules.rst
│   │   └── package.rst
│   ├── _static
│   └── _templates
└── package
    ├── __init__.py
    └── test.py
```
```
$ sphinx-apidoc -f -q -o package ../package -M 
```
**Expected behavior**
`package.rst` ends with a single newline instead of two.

---

From what I could quickly gather from the codebase this can be easily resolved by adding:
```python
if text.endswith('\n\n'):
  text = text[:-1]
```
to `def write_file(name: str, text: str, opts: Any) -> None:` in `apidoc.py`

items.title: Autodoc extension's mock file throws TypeError for generic-typed classes.
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
When building the docs for a generically-typed class, a TypeError is thrown as Autodoc's `mock._make_subclass` attempts to concatenate a `str` to a `TypeVar`. See the attached log: [sphinx-err-325ndteh.log](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/files/4842672/sphinx-err-325ndteh.log)


**To Reproduce**
```
$ git https://github.com/perrygoy/screenpy.git
$ cd screenpy/docs
$ python -m venv env
$ source env/bin/activate
$ pip install sphinx pyhamcrest selenium typing_extensions
$ make html
```
Observe the docs command fails with a TypeError.

**Expected behavior**
Docs can still be built when generics are involved.

**Your project**
https://github.com/perrygoy/screenpy.git

**Environment info**
- OS: Mac 10.15.5 (19F101)

items.title: autosummary spuriously removes spaces and appends an extra dot to the summary line in some cases
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

In some circumstances, autosummary spuriously removes spaces and appends an extra dot to the summary line.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```
$ sphinx-quickstart --sep -m -p foo -a author -r0 -len --extensions sphinx.ext.autosummary
```
edit `index.html` to contain
```
.. autosummary::
   foo.foo
```
and `foo.py` to contain
```
def foo():
    """
    Do `this <https://www.google.com>`_ and that.  Pretend this line is really
    long and has some interesting contents.
    """
```
then build with `make html` and open the built docs.

This results in 
![test](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1322974/85426853-4ddaa100-b57b-11ea-8bc2-e1b78198de4c.png)
i.e. the docstring has a space missing after `that.`, and an extra dot at the end.

**Expected behavior**

A space after `that.`, and no extra dot at the end.

**Environment info**
- OS: linux
- Python version: 3.8.1
- Sphinx version: 3.1.0
- Sphinx extensions:  autosummary

**Additional context**
N/A

items.title: autosummary "first-sentence" detection fails in presence of abbreviations.
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

If a docstring's first sentence contains an abbreviation such as `i.e.`, autosummary incorrectly cuts the summary immediately after the abbreviation.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```
$ sphinx-quickstart --sep -m -p foo -a author -r0 -len --extensions sphinx.ext.autosummary
```
edit `index.html` to contain
```
.. autosummary::
   foo.foo
```
and `foo.py` to contain
```
def foo():
    """
    Does foo, i.e. fooing the thing.
    """
```
then build with `make html` and open the built docs.

This results in 
![test](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1322974/85424765-9b094380-b578-11ea-90df-73c82a6e4fce.png)
i.e. the docstring summary is cut.

**Expected behavior**

Not cutting the summary.

The summary detection logic is at https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/blob/3.x/sphinx/ext/autosummary/__init__.py#L526 (basically splitting at dots followed by whitespace).  I can think of two ways for fixing it: either check that the dot is not followed by a lowercase character, or just special-case `i.e.` and perhaps a couple of other abbreviations.

**Environment info**
- OS: linux
- Python version: 3.8.1
- Sphinx version: 3.1.0
- Sphinx extensions:  autosummary

**Additional context**
N/A

items.title: autodoc + intersphinx: Document module members as though they were part of another module
items.body:
Say I have a project like this:
```
my_package/
    __init__.py
    my_module.py
    my_other_module.py
```
Contents of `my_module.py`:
```python
def my_func():
    "doc for my_func"

def my_other_func():
    "doc for my_other_func"
```
Contents of `__init__.py`:
```python
from .my_module import *
from .my_other_module import *
```
Now I want to use the `automodule` directive to document all functions in `my_module.py`:
```rst
.. automodule:: my_package.my_module
```
The problem with this is that it registers the functions as members of `my_package.my_module`, but I want them to be members of `my_package`. Intersphinx shows the problem:
```
~> python -m sphinx.ext.intersphinx docs/build/html/objects.inv
py:function
	my_package.my_module.my_function          foo.html#my_package.my_module.my_function 
	my_package.my_module.my_other_function    foo.html#my_package.my_module.my_other_function 
```
I'd like this to be
```
py:function
	my_package.my_function          foo.html#my_package.my_function 
	my_package.my_other_function    foo.html#my_package.my_other_function 
```
instead.

**Workaround**
The workaround, of course, is to manually document all members of `my_module` with `autofunction`/`autoclass` directives. This is a huge hassle if the module contains a lot of stuff.

**Suggested solution**
Make the `automodule` directive accept a modifier that makes it masquerade as another module, for example like so:
```rst
.. automodule:: my_package.my_module
   :as-module: my_package
```

items.title: autodoc strips trailing underscores from function parameters' names
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Function parameters documented with the `:param` syntax have underscores stripped from their names.

**To Reproduce**
With a function like this:
```python
def testfunc(type_):
    """
    :param type_: lorem ipsum
    """
```
And documentation like this:
```rst
.. autofunction:: my_module.testfunc
```
The output generated by `make html` looks like this:
```
testfunc(type_)
    Parameters
        type – lorem ipsum
```
The function signature is correct, but in the "Parameters" section the parameter's name is wrong.

**Expected behavior**
The documentation should show the correct parameter name, i.e. `type_`.

**Environment info**
- OS: Manjaro linux
- Python version: 3.8.3
- Sphinx version: 3.1.1
- Sphinx extensions:  sphinx.ext.autodoc

items.title: Support for parameterized GNU style attributes on C++ code.
items.body:
Hi folks.

My C++ codebase uses GNU attributes for code like 

`__attribute__ ((optimize(3))) void readMatrix(void)`

Unfortunately, it looks like Sphinx doesn't support them. 

```
Exception occurred:
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/sphinx/domains/cpp.py", line 6099, in _parse_type
    raise self._make_multi_error(prevErrors, header)
sphinx.util.cfamily.DefinitionError: Error when parsing function declaration.
If the function has no return type:
  Invalid C++ declaration: Parameterized GNU style attribute not yet supported. [error at 25]
    __attribute__ ((optimize(3))) void readMatrix(void)
    -------------------------^
If the function has a return type:
  Invalid C++ declaration: Parameterized GNU style attribute not yet supported. [error at 25]
    __attribute__ ((optimize(3))) void readMatrix(void)
    -------------------------^
```

I'm running Sphinx 3.1.1, though this functionality doesn't appear to have changed in 4.

I tried to get clever with the custom attribute support you offer, but can't seem to get that to work either.
```
cpp_id_attributes = ["aligned","packed","weak","always_inline","noinline","no-unroll-loops","__attribute__((optimize(3)))"]
cpp_paren_attributes = ["optimize","__aligned__","section","deprecated"]
```

Is there a right way to do this? I'd honestly be fine having the attributes stripped entirely for doc generation if there isn't another option.

Even though I'm bumping up against a sharp edge, I really appreciate Sphinx. Thanks so much for making a useful tool.

items.title: Code blocks with :linenos: are not accessible to blind people
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
When the screen reader reads the code block, it starts to say "1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, ..." and, after all numbers, it reads the code.

**To Reproduce**
Just create a code block with linenos (and more than one line of code), and try to read it with a screen reader.

**Expected behavior**
The screen reader will read "1 first line of code, 2 second line of code, ...) or, better, permit to browse the code like a table (with a real table or aria properties).

**Environment info**
- OS: Linux
- Python version: All
- Sphinx version: 3.1.1
- Sphinx extensions: none
- Extra tools: Firefox or Chromium and Orca

**Additional context**
The problem here is the structure of the code block. It's generated in a table with a single line. One cell contains all numbers and one all lines of code. It's impossible to the screen reader to associate a number to a line of code, and the user can't get advantage of line numbers. Fixing this can fix issue #1007.

items.title: Sphinx autodoc includes imported modules even when :private-members: is not set
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
I'm building documentation for my python project with sphinx and autodoc. I have autodoc defaults including `members: True` and `undoc-members: True`. However, I have not set `private-members`. When I build my docs, autodoc documents modules that my modules have imported. But I don't want that, I don't consider those part of my module's public interface, and Pep8 says [here](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#public-and-internal-interfaces) that those modules are considered part of the private interface. I think autodoc should not be documenting imported modules unless the `private-members` flag is set.

**To Reproduce**
This minimal setup should work:
```
#foo.py
from . import bar
```
where `bar.py` is in the same folder as `foo.py`. autodoc should not be documenting bar, but is. 

**Your project**
* checkout [this commit of my project](https://github.com/gymreklab/TRTools/tree/157a332b49f2be0b12c2d5ae38312d83a175a851)
* remove the line  `:exclude-members: Line2D` from `doc/trtools.compareSTR.rst`
* `cd doc && make clean && make html` to build the docs - you'll see Line2D appears all over the compareSTR docs.

**Environment info**
- OS: Unix
- Python version: 3.7
- Sphinx version: 3.0.4
- Sphinx extensions:  sphinx.ext.autodoc (my project also uses napoleon, though that's tangential)

items.title: deactivate ext based on builder
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I use the viewcode extension for my html builds. But for my confluence builds (made with `sphinxcontrib-confluencebuilder`) I don't want this extension active.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I think it would only be doable within the `setup()` function in the `conf.py` file. So I want a way to deactivate extensions or activate them from there.

When `self.buildername = buildername` is added to the beginning of `application.Sphinx.__init__` one could get the builder's name inside the `setup()` via `app.buildername`. Then one could conditionally remove ext from the list like so:
```python
def setup(app):
    if app.buildername == "confluence":
        app.config.extensions.remove("sphinx.ext.viewcode")
```

Problem:
And if I understand the code correctly the extensions are initialized before the `setup()` is run. So could the setup part be put before the extension init?

Workaround could be to do it the other way around and instead of removing an extension call `app.setup_extension` with the extension to initialize manually in the user `conf.py`? But I think maybe the setup call needs to be placed before the `preload_builder` call?

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
One way would be to write multiple `conf.py` and put them in directories to choose them with `-c`.

items.title: Sphinx v3.1.1 causing errors for autodocumenting due to import confusion
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

The `pyhf` docs build without errors with [Sphinx `v3.0.4`](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/releases/tag/v3.0.4) but they are broken by [Sphinx `v3.1.1`](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/releases/tag/v3.1.1). Specifically, the docs are breaking due to `autodocumenting` fialing to import the right module, and hence failing to produce the documentation for two sections of the API. This is shown during the build by

```
WARNING: don't know which module to import for autodocumenting 'optimize.opt_jax.jax_optimizer' (try placing a "module" or "currentmodule" directive in the document, or giving an explicit module name)
WARNING: don't know which module to import for autodocumenting 'optimize.opt_minuit.minuit_optimizer' (try placing a "module" or "currentmodule" directive in the document, or giving an explicit module name)
WARNING: don't know which module to import for autodocumenting 'optimize.opt_pytorch.pytorch_optimizer' (try placing a "module" or "currentmodule" directive in the document, or giving an explicit module name)
WARNING: don't know which module to import for autodocumenting 'optimize.opt_scipy.scipy_optimizer' (try placing a "module" or "currentmodule" directive in the document, or giving an explicit module name)
WARNING: don't know which module to import for autodocumenting 'optimize.opt_tflow.tflow_optimizer' (try placing a "module" or "currentmodule" directive in the document, or giving an explicit module name)
WARNING: don't know which module to import for autodocumenting 'tensor.jax_backend.jax_backend' (try placing a "module" or "currentmodule" directive in the document, or giving an explicit module name)
WARNING: don't know which module to import for autodocumenting 'tensor.numpy_backend.numpy_backend' (try placing a "module" or "currentmodule" directive in the document, or giving an explicit module name)
WARNING: don't know which module to import for autodocumenting 'tensor.pytorch_backend.pytorch_backend' (try placing a "module" or "currentmodule" directive in the document, or giving an explicit module name)
WARNING: don't know which module to import for autodocumenting 'tensor.tensorflow_backend.tensorflow_backend' (try placing a "module" or "currentmodule" directive in the document, or giving an explicit module name)
```

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```
# In a fresh Python 3.7 virtual environment after running
# python -m pip --upgrade pip setuptools wheel

$ git clone https://github.com/scikit-hep/pyhf.git
$ cd pyhf
$ python -m pip install .[docs]
$ cd docs
$ make html # errors during build
```

**Expected behavior**

The above commands build without error for [Sphinx `v3.0.4`](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/releases/tag/v3.0.4), so the same behavior is expected for the minor and patch release bump to [Sphinx `v3.1.1`](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/releases/tag/v3.1.1).

**Your project**

Our project is [`pyhf`](https://github.com/scikit-hep/pyhf) and our nightly CI build of the docs catches this.

**Environment info**

Our CI that runs the docs is using [GitHub Actions with the following YAML](https://github.com/scikit-hep/pyhf/blob/02e9543f9d19bdabb0bd4cedf14f687d354976a6/.github/workflows/ci.yml#L82-L120)

```
  docs:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    strategy:
      matrix:
        python-version: [3.7]
    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v2
      with:
        fetch-depth: 0
    - name: Set up Python 3.7
      uses: actions/setup-python@v2
      with:
        python-version: ${{ matrix.python-version }}
```

which results in

- OS: Ubuntu 16.04
- Python version: 3.7.7
- Sphinx version: 3.1.0
- Sphinx extensions: [[sphinx.ext.autodoc, sphinx.ext.autosummary, sphinx.ext.coverage, sphinx.ext.mathjax, sphinx.ext.ifconfig, sphinx.ext.viewcode, sphinx.ext.githubpages, sphinxcontrib.bibtex, sphinx.ext.napoleon, sphinx_click.ext, nbsphinx, sphinx_issues, sphinx_copybutton, xref]](https://github.com/scikit-hep/pyhf/blob/e1d22ba6986eb117cb0ce810bbe5ede42ea0be10/docs/conf.py#L42-L57)

**Additional context**
This is also [`pyhf` Issue 897](https://github.com/scikit-hep/pyhf/issues/897)

cc @lukasheinrich @kratsg

I'm also not sure if this has any overlap with Sphinx Issue #7841 or not.

items.title: Sphinx 3.1.1 name clash prevents autodoc importing.
items.body:
Sphinx 3.1.1 seems to have changed the way that autodoc finds python imports which leads to two kinds of failure in building the sympy docs. Effectively the change is the difference between
```python
from sympy.series.order import Order
```
compared to this
```python
import sympy
Order = sympy.series.order
```
These are not equivalent and there are many cases in sympy where only the former works so autodoc fails to find many objects in sympy now.

This is a simple view of the relevant module structure in sympy:
```
sympy/
    __init__.py
    series/
        __init__.py
        order.py
        series.py
```
In order.py there is a class called `Order` and in series.py there is a function called `series`. The main sympy/__init__.py effectively does
```python
# Import the series function
from .series.series import series
```
In this setup the Order class can be imported as
```python
>>> from sympy.series.order import Order
>>> Order
<class 'sympy.series.order.Order'>
```
However it cannot be accessed through attributes from `sympy` e.g.:
```python
>>> import sympy
>>> sympy.series.order.Order
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: 'function' object has no attribute 'order'
>>> sympy.series
<function series at 0x104fa4ca0>
```

This is the same error as seen when building the sphinx docs:
```
WARNING: autodoc: failed to import class 'series.order.Order' from
module 'sympy'; the following exception was raised:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/enojb/current/sympy/38venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sphinx/util/inspect.py",
line 324, in safe_getattr
    return getattr(obj, name, *defargs)
AttributeError: 'function' object has no attribute 'order'
```
This is because `getattr` is being used rather than `importlib` to locate the import. These are not generally equivalent and it seems that sphinx 3.1.1 has switched from using one to use the other.

There is another issue when attempting to reproduce this which is that there are many deprecated import objects in `sympy/__init__.py` and calling `getattr` on them triggers a deprecation warning:
https://github.com/sympy/sympy/pull/19554

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```
$ git clone https://github.com/sympy/sympy.git
$ cd sympy
$ pip install mpmath
$ pip install -e .
$ cd docs
$ make html
```

**Expected behavior**
The docs would build successfully without warning like they do in 3.1.0

**Your project**

This was already mentioned on the sphinx mailing list:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/sphinx-users/mx83xLsDjBs/Qc3jW-z7AQAJ
Corresponding sympy issue:
https://github.com/sympy/sympy/issues/19551

items.title: 'updating environment' intensively computed and pausing for a long time
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
running command:
```bash
$ sphinx-build -b html -D language=<my 2 digits language code> ./manual "build/html<language_location>"
```
and always encountered the 'updating environment' and computer pausing for a longtime.

**To Reproduce**
Go here:
https://docs.blender.org/manual/en/2.83/about/index.html

and follows the 'Install', 'Build' instructions for the OS you have.

Then go here:
https://docs.blender.org/manual/en/2.83/about/contribute/translations/contribute.html

to read how to download a foreign language set of your choice. You can see the list of languages available at the moment at this link:
https://svn.blender.org/svnroot/bf-manual-translations/trunk/blender_docs/locale/

Configure the file
```bash
manual/conf.py
```
and choose the language matches the set you've downloaded, then in the 'blender_docs' directory, run the command:
```bash
make html
```
now jump into the
```bash
blender_docs/locale/<language you download>/LC_MESSAGES
```
and edit any files.

then run:
```bash
$ sphinx-build -b html -D language=<2 digits language code> ./manual "build/html"
```
you should see the message 'updating environment' and the pausing could take up to one to two minutes, which is VERY UNUSUAL

**Expected behavior**
With a very small amount of changes, the code should run very quick, a couple seconds max.

**Your project**
https://docs.blender.org/manual/en/latest/

**Screenshots**
N/A

**Environment info**
- OS: Operating system: Darwin-19.4.0-x86_64-i386-64bit 64 Bits

**Additional context**
Debugging the code and found the problem occurs in the 
```bash
sphinx/environment/__init__.py
```
at the routine:

```py
 def find_files(self, config: Config, builder: "Builder") -> None:
```
in the class:
```py
class BuildEnvironment:
```
The code was trying to find an EXACT MATCH for doc name in self.found_docs and the catalog.domain, and thus looping recursively through a LARGE LIST of files.

I have found a fix for this problem, by splitting the loop to find all doc name in self.found_docs to a separate loop, digest the value of domain then store this to a dictionary
```py
entry = {domain_hash_digest: doc name}
```
then later in the catalog search loop, perform the same digest function on catalog.domain, and using the 'in' comparing function to get the EXACT MATCH. This has speeding up the code enormously.

this is the entire block of code I use:

```py
import hashlib 

    def find_files(self, config: Config, builder: "Builder") -> None:
        """Find all source files in the source dir and put them in
        self.found_docs.
        """
        domain_list = {}
        try:
            exclude_paths = (self.config.exclude_patterns +
                             self.config.templates_path +
                             builder.get_asset_paths())
            self.project.discover(exclude_paths)

            # Current implementation is applying translated messages in the reading
            # phase.Therefore, in order to apply the updated message catalog, it is
            # necessary to re-process from the reading phase. Here, if dependency
            # is set for the doc source and the mo file, it is processed again from
            # the reading phase when mo is updated. In the future, we would like to
            # move i18n process into the writing phase, and remove these lines.
            if builder.use_message_catalog:
                # add catalog mo file dependency
                repo = CatalogRepository(self.srcdir, self.config.locale_dirs,
                                         self.config.language, self.config.source_encoding)
                logger.info(f'repo:{repo}', nonl=False)

                for docname in self.found_docs:
                    domain = docname_to_domain(docname, self.config.gettext_compact)
                    domain_hash = hashlib.sha512(domain.encode('utf-8'))
                    domain_hash_digest = domain_hash.digest()
                    entry = {domain_hash_digest: docname}
                    # print(f'hash_entry: {entry}')
                    domain_list.update(entry)

                for catalog in repo.catalogs:
                    catalog_hash = hashlib.sha512(catalog.domain.encode('utf-8'))
                    catalog_hash_digest = catalog_hash.digest()
                    is_in = (catalog_hash_digest in domain_list)
                    # print(f'looking for: {catalog_hash_digest}, catalog.domain:{catalog.domain} catalog.mo_path:{catalog.mo_path}')
                    if is_in:
                        docname = domain_list[catalog_hash_digest]
                        # print(f'found docname: {docname}, catalog.mo_path: {catalog.mo_path}')
                        self.dependencies[docname].add(catalog.mo_path)
        except OSError as exc:
            raise DocumentError(__('Failed to scan documents in %s: %r') % (self.srcdir, exc))
```
Sorry, I do not have a facility to produce 'diff' file.

items.title: autosummary cannot handle umlauts in function names on Windows.
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

I want to use `autosummary` to document functions which contain German umlauts like ä, ö, ü. As an example, I use the following directive
```rst
.. autosummary::
   :toctree: _generated

   mypackage.module
```
The sub file is successfully generated in `docs/_generated/mypackage.module.rst`, but the encoding is `Western (Windows 1252)` which produces similar warnings during the build

```
reading sources... [100%] functions/_generated/gettsim.soz_vers.krankenv_pflegev
xxx\gettsim\docs\functions\_generated\gettsim.soz_vers.krankenv_pflegev.rst:20: WARNING: undecodable source characters, replacing with "?": b'      bezugsgr>>>\xf6<<<\xdfe\r'
xxx\gettsim\docs\functions\_generated\gettsim.soz_vers.krankenv_pflegev.rst:20: WARNING: undecodable source characters, replacing with "?": b'      bezugsgr\xf6>>>\xdf<<<e\r'
```

Converting the encoding of the file to `utf-8` and setting `autosummary_generate_overwrite = False`. Solves the issue.

**To Reproduce**

*Skipped*

**Expected behavior**

No warnings. Same output as here (https://gettsim--197.org.readthedocs.build/en/197/functions/_generated/gettsim.soz_vers.krankenv_pflegev.html#gettsim.soz_vers.krankenv_pflegev.bezugsgrosze). For example, function `bezugsgröße()`.

**Your project**

- [no error in rtd log because ubuntu](https://readthedocs.org/projects/gettsim/builds/11256848/)
- [the pr where the issue occurred](https://github.com/iza-institute-of-labor-economics/gettsim/pull/197)

**Environment info**
- OS: Windows
- Python version: 3.7.6
- Sphinx version: 3.1.1
- Sphinx extensions:  sphinx.ext.autosummary

items.title: List items have extra vertical space since Sphinx 3.1.x
items.body:
**Describe the bug** List items in HTML output are displayed with extra vertical space, as if separated by blank lines. Compare the rendering of the feature list in this project, or the screenshots further below: - https://cookiecutter-hypermodern-python.readthedocs.io/en/2020.5.15/ (Sphinx 3.0.3) - https://cookiecutter-hypermodern-python.readthedocs.io/en/2020.6.15/ (Sphinx 3.1.0) Tested on a recent Chrome for Mac, see below for environment info. It appears this is due to changes in `basic.css` between Sphinx 3.0.4 and 3.1.0. See the diff of `basic.css` at the bottom of this issue description. The stylesheet rules reset the bottom margin of `

` when nested in `

  • `. Apparently this logic was broken in Sphinx 3.1.x for at least one browser. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior: ``` $ git clone https://github.com/cjolowicz/cookiecutter-hypermodern-python $ git checkout 2020.6.15 $ cd cookiecutter-hypermodern-python $ pip install -r docs/requirements.txt $ cd docs $ sphinx-build . _build $ open _build/index.html ``` **Expected behavior** List items are displayed in a compact way, without vertical spacing amounting to blank line. **Your project** https://github.com/cjolowicz/cookiecutter-hypermodern-python **Screenshots** With Sphinx 3.0.3: With Sphinx 3.1.0: **Environment info** - OS: macOS Mojave 10.14.6 (18G4032) - Python version: 3.8.2 - Sphinx version: 3.1.0, 3.1.1 - Sphinx extensions: - - Extra tools: Chrome 83.0.4103.97 (Official Build) (64-bit) **Additional context** Here is the diff of basic.css from Sphinx 3.0.4 to 3.1.0 which causes the breakage for me. IOW if I revert these changes, the list is displayed correctly. ```diff diff --git a/_static/basic.css b/_static/basic.css index 3a37f63..56f5efc 100644 --- a/_static/basic.css +++ b/_static/basic.css @@ -513,14 +513,30 @@ ol.upperroman { list-style: upper-roman; } -li > p:first-child { +ol > li:first-child > :first-child, +ul > li:first-child > :first-child { margin-top: 0px; } -li > p:last-child { +ol ol > li:first-child > :first-child, +ol ul > li:first-child > :first-child, +ul ol > li:first-child > :first-child, +ul ul > li:first-child > :first-child { + margin-top: revert; +} + +ol > li:last-child > :last-child, +ul > li:last-child > :last-child { margin-bottom: 0px; } +ol ol > li:last-child > :last-child, +ol ul > li:last-child > :last-child, +ul ol > li:last-child > :last-child, +ul ul > li:last-child > :last-child { + margin-bottom: revert; +} + dl.footnote > dt, dl.citation > dt { float: left; ```

items.title: Display property return typehints
items.body:
**Problem:**
Unless I missed some configuration, property return typehints are not displayed in the output documentation with *sphinx.ext.autodoc*.

**Suggestion:**
As #7068 states, it is convenient to have properties being displayed the same as attributes.
It would be nice if the property return typehints were used as the type of the *pseudo attributes*.

**Alternatives:**
#7385 tells about the `:type:` directive that we could use in the property docstrings but:
- this is redundant information with the return typehint,
- it does not display the same as attributes.

**Example:**
In the screenshot below:
- `time` is an instance attribute with typehint: `# type: TimeStats`,
- `actions` is a property with return typehint: `# type: (...) -> ExecTotalStats`,
- `steps` is a property with return typehint: `# type: (...) -> ExecTotalStats`, plus a `:type: ExecTotalStats` in its docstring.
---
![2020-06-15 004735](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41943581/84606002-3415cb80-aea2-11ea-9235-20fcb63b06ea.png)
---
It would be nice if we had property lines ending with "*: ExecTotalStats*".
Adding a `:type: ExecTotalStats` directive in the `steps` property docstring does not display the information the same way as the `time` attribute.

**Configuration:**
- *sphinx-build* version 3.0.4
- use of the *sphinx.ext.autodoc* extension (*sphix.ext.napoleon* seems to behave the same for that concern)

items.title: List of Listings has a broken format
items.body:
**Latex PDF creation with XELATEX has broken TOC format**
`\lstlistoflistings` creates a broken format of TOC unlike list of figures or list of tables.

**To Reproduce**

1. Create a sphinx documentation with quickstart
2. add a "latex_elements"  **preamble** to use "listings" package
```
\usepackage{listings}
```
3. add a few listings in a .rst file like below - and add it in `toctree` of `index.rst`
```
.. code-block:: shell
   :caption: Make PDF with sphinx

   cd docs/
   make latexpdf
 ```
4. add the following in another .rst file and add the file in "index.rst" toctree
```
.. raw:: latex

   \begingroup
   \lstlistoflistings
   \clearpage

.. raw:: latex

   \endgroup
```

**Expected behavior**
The expected behavior would be to produce a list of "Listings" with a similar format as "List of Tables" or
"List of Figures"

**Screenshots**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5631766/84568529-4b5c9800-ad80-11ea-84e0-50975865945c.png)


**Environment info**
- OS: Ubuntu 18.04, Ubuntu 20.04
- Python version: 3.6.9, 3.7.4, 3.8.2
- Sphinx version: 3.0.1, 3.0.4
- Extra tools: xelatex as latex engine

items.title: No module named error prevent sphinx to document code
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Hello,

I am currently working on a project where I try to use sphinx to generate the documentation however I am facing multiple "No module named [MODULE NAME]" with [MODULE NAME] being one of the module of my project. Because of this error some modules are not documented by Sphinx. When trying to run those modules directly (with "python [MODULE NAME].py") everything is  ok. Here is the project's tree : 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38282930/84535066-587b7780-aceb-11ea-85c3-8775d7f31125.png)

**To Reproduce**
For you to be able to recreate the issue I created a repository called "sphinx_test" that you can find here :
https://github.com/Nighthyst/sphinx_test

Once you downloaded the repository, you just have to go inside the docs folder and run the command "make html". Then I have the following output in the terminal :  
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38282930/84532017-cb81ef80-ace5-11ea-8073-2eeb5d9ae7eb.png)

As you can see problems occured for "autre" and "example" modules. So the documentation looks like this : 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38282930/84532166-0dab3100-ace6-11ea-81c0-8945271afbb4.png)

Everything is empty for "example" and "autre". To reproduce the bug, open a terminal and run the following commands : 

```
$ git clone https://github.com/Nighthyst/sphinx_test.git
$ cd sphinx_test
$ cd docs
$ make html
$ # open docs/build/html/index.html and see the documentation
```

**Expected behavior**
No warning for "autre" and "example" modules. Documentation for them too.

**Your project**
https://github.com/Nighthyst/sphinx_test

**Environment info**
- OS: Windows 10 Professional 
- Python version: 3.7.6
- Sphinx version: 3.1.0
- Sphinx extensions:  sphinx.ext.autodoc
- Extra tools: Firefox\

items.title: Sphinx v3.1.0 causing errors in autoclass directive and missing title toctreee reference
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

The `pyhf` docs build without errors with [Sphinx `v3.0.4`](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/releases/tag/v3.0.4) but they are broken by [Sphinx `v3.1.0`](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/releases/tag/v3.1.0). Specifically, the docs are breaking with errors of the form

```
path-to-project/docs/_generated/<code module>.rst:8 WARNING: Error in "autoclass" directive:
1 argument(s) required, 0 supplied.

.. autoclass::
   :show-inheritance:







   .. rubric:: Methods



   .. automethod:: .__init__
```

and

```
<partial node>:: WARNING: toctree contains reference to document '_generated/<code module>' that doesn't have a title: no link will be generated
```

A clear and concise description of what the bug is.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```
<Paste your command-line here which cause the problem>
# In a fresh Python 3.7 virtual environment after running
# python -m pip --upgrade pip setuptools wheel

$ git clone https://github.com/scikit-hep/pyhf.git
$ cd pyhf
$ python -m pip install .[docs]
$ cd docs
$ make html # errors during build
```

I have [attached the full error output](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/files/4756060/sphinx-v3.1.0-error-log.txt) of

```
make html &> sphinx-v3.1.0-error-log.txt
```

**Expected behavior**

The above commands build without error for [Sphinx `v3.0.4`](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/releases/tag/v3.0.4), so the same behavior is expected for the minor release bump to [Sphinx `v3.1.0`](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/releases/tag/v3.1.0).

**Your project**

Our project is [`pyhf`](https://github.com/scikit-hep/pyhf) and our nightly CI build of the docs catches this.

**Environment info**

Our CI that runs the docs is using [GitHub Actions with the following YAML](https://github.com/scikit-hep/pyhf/blob/02e9543f9d19bdabb0bd4cedf14f687d354976a6/.github/workflows/ci.yml#L82-L120)

```
  docs:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    strategy:
      matrix:
        python-version: [3.7]
    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v2
      with:
        fetch-depth: 0
    - name: Set up Python 3.7
      uses: actions/setup-python@v2
      with:
        python-version: ${{ matrix.python-version }}
```

which results in

- OS: Ubuntu 16.04
- Python version: 3.7.7
- Sphinx version: 3.1.0
- Sphinx extensions: [[sphinx.ext.autodoc, sphinx.ext.autosummary, sphinx.ext.coverage, sphinx.ext.mathjax, sphinx.ext.ifconfig, sphinx.ext.viewcode, sphinx.ext.githubpages, sphinxcontrib.bibtex, sphinx.ext.napoleon, sphinx_click.ext, nbsphinx, sphinx_issues, sphinx_copybutton, xref]](https://github.com/scikit-hep/pyhf/blob/e1d22ba6986eb117cb0ce810bbe5ede42ea0be10/docs/conf.py#L42-L57)

**Additional context**
This is also [`pyhf` Issue 894](https://github.com/scikit-hep/pyhf/issues/894)

cc @lukasheinrich @kratsg
